payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!

content.text:
<user_instructions>

# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!



</user_instructions>

{"output":"CC       := x86_64-elf-gcc
LD       := x86_64-elf-ld
OBJCOPY  := x86_64-elf-objcopy
QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64
HOST_CC  ?= cc

SRC_DIR     := src
ARCH_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/arch/x86
KERNEL_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/kernel
DRIVER_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/drivers
ATK_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/atk
NET_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/net
SBIN_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/sbin
CRYPTO_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/crypto
INCLUDE_DIR := include
USER_DIR    := user
OBJDIR      := build

CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
          -m64 -mno-red-zone -mgeneral-regs-only -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR) -I$(ATK_DIR) \
          -fno-merge-constants -fno-asynchronous-unwind-tables -fno-unwind-tables \
          -fshort-wchar

KERNEL_LD   := $(ARCH_DIR)/uefi.ld
LOADER_DIR  := src/loader

ARCH_KERNEL_SOURCES := $(filter-out $(ARCH_DIR)/uefi_boot.c,$(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.c))

C_SOURCES := \
	$(wildcard $(KERNEL_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(DRIVER_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/util/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(NET_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(CRYPTO_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(ARCH_KERNEL_SOURCES) \
	$(wildcard $(SBIN_DIR)/*.c)

C_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(C_SOURCES))

ASM_SOURCES := $(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.S)
ASM_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.S,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(ASM_SOURCES))

USER_OBJDIR := $(OBJDIR)/user
USER_CFLAGS := $(CFLAGS) -I$(USER_DIR) -I$(ATK_DIR) -DATK_NO_DESKTOP_APPS -DVIDEO_WIDTH=640 -DVIDEO_HEIGHT=360
USER_COMMON_SOURCES := \
	$(USER_DIR)/crt0.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/syscall.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/libc.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/atk_user.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/video_surface.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/serial_stub.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/atk_user_host_stub.c
USER_COMMON_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(USER_DIR)/%.c,$(USER_OBJDIR)/%.o,$(USER_COMMON_SOURCES))
USER_COMMON_OBJECTS += $(USER_OBJDIR)/kernel/font.o
USER_LD_SCRIPT := $(USER_DIR)/link.ld
USER_ATK_SOURCES := $(filter-out $(ATK_DIR)/atk_shell.c $(ATK_DIR)/atk_task_manager.c,$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/*.c))
USER_ATK_SOURCES += $(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/util/*.c)
USER_ATK_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(USER_OBJDIR)/%.o,$(USER_ATK_SOURCES))
USER_ELFS := $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.elf $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.elf
USER_BIN_DIR := build/bin
USER_BINS := $(USER_BIN_DIR)/userdemo2 $(USER_BIN_DIR)/atk_demo

KERNEL_ELF := $(OBJDIR)/alix.elf
EFI_DIR    := build/EFI/BOOT
EFI_BIN    := $(EFI_DIR)/BOOTX64.EFI
DATA_IMG   := data.img
LOADER_SRC := $(LOADER_DIR)/uefi_loader.c
LOADER_CC  ?= x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc
LOADER_CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
                 -mno-red-zone -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR) -fshort-wchar
LOADER_LDFLAGS := -nostdlib -Wl,--dll -Wl,--entry=efi_main -Wl,--subsystem,10 \
                  -Wl,--image-base,0x4000000 -Wl,--file-alignment,0x200 -Wl,--section-alignment,0x1000 \
                  -Wl,--major-subsystem-version,10 -Wl,--minor-subsystem-version,0

all: $(KERNEL_ELF) $(EFI_BIN) $(USER_ELFS) $(USER_BINS)

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.S
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/%.o: $(USER_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/atk/%.o: $(ATK_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/atk/util/%.o: $(ATK_DIR)/util/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/kernel/%.o: $(KERNEL_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(KERNEL_ELF): $(C_OBJECTS) $(ASM_OBJECTS) $(KERNEL_LD)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -z max-page-size=0x1000 -T $(KERNEL_LD) -o $@ $(C_OBJECTS) $(ASM_OBJECTS)

$(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.elf: $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.o $(USER_LD_SCRIPT)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(USER_LD_SCRIPT) -o $@ $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.o

$(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.elf: $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_ATK_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.o $(USER_LD_SCRIPT)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(USER_LD_SCRIPT) -o $@ $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_ATK_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.o

$(USER_BIN_DIR)/userdemo2: $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.elf
	@mkdir -p $(USER_BIN_DIR)
	cp $< $@

$(USER_BIN_DIR)/atk_demo: $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.elf
	@mkdir -p $(USER_BIN_DIR)
	cp $< $@

LOADER_HEADERS := \
	$(INCLUDE_DIR)/uefi.h \
	$(INCLUDE_DIR)/bootinfo.h \
	$(INCLUDE_DIR)/arch/x86/bootlayout.h

$(EFI_BIN): $(LOADER_SRC) $(KERNEL_ELF) $(LOADER_HEADERS)
	@mkdir -p $(EFI_DIR)
	$(LOADER_CC) $(LOADER_CFLAGS) $(LOADER_LDFLAGS) -o $@ $<

$(DATA_IMG):
	truncate -s 4G $@

RAM ?= 4G
OVMF_CODE ?= vendor/OVMF_CODE.fd
OVMF_VARS ?= vendor/OVMF_VARS-1024x768.fd
QEMU_DEBUG_LOG   ?= qemu.log
QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS ?= -d cpu_reset,int,guest_errors,trace:ahci_*,trace:ide_*,trace:cmd_identify -D $(QEMU_DEBUG_LOG)
HOMEBREW_PREFIX  := $(shell brew --prefix)

# --- choose networking backend: user (slirp), vmnet-shared (NAT), vmnet-bridged (bridge en0)
NET_BACKEND ?= vmnet-shared

# Packet capture (works for all backends)
NETDUMP := -object filter-dump,id=n0dump,netdev=n0,queue=all,file=qemu-net.pcap

# Backend-specific NETDEV flags
NETDEV_user := -netdev user,id=n0,net=10.0.2.0/24,dhcpstart=10.0.2.15

# Defaults
QEMU_NET_PREFIX :=
NETDEV := $(NETDEV_user)

# vmnet-shared via socket_vmnet (rootless): wrap QEMU and use fd=3
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-shared)
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# vmnet-bridged via socket_vmnet (rootless): choose interface with VMNET_BRIDGE=en0/en1/...
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-bridged)
  VMNET_BRIDGE ?= en0
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet.bridged.$(VMNET_BRIDGE)
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# Device (keep RTL8139 + MAC)
NIC := -device rtl8139,netdev=n0,mac=52:54:00:12:34:56

run: $(EFI_BIN) $(DATA_IMG) $(USER_ELFS) $(USER_BINS)
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \
	$(QEMU) -nodefaults -m $(RAM) -machine q35,accel=kvm:tcg \
		-drive if=pflash,unit=0,format=raw,readonly=on,file=$(OVMF_CODE) \
		-drive if=pflash,unit=1,format=raw,file=$(OVMF_VARS) \
		-drive if=none,id=fsdisk,file=fat:rw:build,format=raw \
		-device ahci,id=ahci0 \
		-device ide-hd,drive=fsdisk,bus=ahci0.0 \
		-drive if=none,id=data,file=$(DATA_IMG),format=raw,media=disk \
		-device ide-hd,drive=data,bus=ahci0.1 \
		-no-reboot -monitor vc:1280x1024 -serial stdio -vga std \
		$(QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS) $(NETDEV) $(NETDUMP) $(NIC)

run-hdd: $(EFI_BIN) $(DATA_IMG) $(USER_ELFS) $(USER_BINS)
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \
	$(QEMU) -nodefaults -m $(RAM) -machine q35,accel=kvm:tcg \
		-drive if=pflash,unit=0,format=raw,readonly=on,file=$(OVMF_CODE) \
		-drive if=pflash,unit=1,format=raw,file=$(OVMF_VARS) \
		-drive if=none,id=fsdisk,file=fat:rw:build,format=raw \
		-device ahci,id=ahci0 \
		-device ide-hd,drive=fsdisk,bus=ahci0.0 \
		-drive if=none,id=data,file=$(DATA_IMG),format=raw,media=disk \
		-device ide-hd,drive=data,bus=ahci0.1 \
		-no-reboot -monitor vc:1280x1024 -serial stdio -vga std \
		$(QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS) $(NETDEV) $(NETDUMP) $(NIC)

clean:
	rm -rf $(OBJDIR) $(DATA_IMG) $(USER_BIN_DIR)

tests/dhcp_packet_test: tests/dhcp_packet_test.c

**Devising TTF library integration plan**

I'm planning how to implement a TrueType font library by wrapping and trimming the public domain `stb_truetype` code to support glyph bitmap rendering with a clean API; Im balancing code location, build integration, and minimal parsing features while preparing to add new source and header files within existing directories for smooth compilation.

**Planning STB TrueType integration**

I'll include the public domain `stb_truetype.h` header in a new `include/vendor` folder to keep things organized and update build flags accordingly. Then Ill design a lightweight TTF API wrapping STB functions for loading fonts, measuring glyphs, and rendering glyph bitmaps, balancing functionality with demo needs and memory management considerations.

payload.text:
**Designing TTF font library API and implementation**

I'm planning an API for loading and rendering TTF fonts using stb_truetype, including font metrics and glyph bitmaps. Ill handle memory carefully by copying font data and integrating stbs allocator with our heap. I want to replicate common font metrics and support basic glyph rendering with offsets and advances. Theres also a note to build a demo app showing glyphs using ATKs drawing APIs. Lots of details to iron out!

payload.text:
**Planning minimal TrueType parser implementation**

This is a hefty challenge! I'm mapping out a step-by-step plan to create a lightweight TrueType font parser that handles key tables like `head`, `cmap`, `glyf`, and supports both simple and composite glyphs, focusing on rendering letters and digits from SF-Pro. To understand complexity, I'm considering writing a Python script to analyze glyph types in the font first, which will guide the C implementation. The end goal is a basic rasterizer using supersampling and flattened quadratic curves to render glyph outlines properly. Its a detailed process, but tackling it incrementally feels promising.

summary.text:
**Planning minimal TrueType parser implementation**

This is a hefty challenge! I'm mapping out a step-by-step plan to create a lightweight TrueType font parser that handles key tables like `head`, `cmap`, `glyf`, and supports both simple and composite glyphs, focusing on rendering letters and digits from SF-Pro. To understand complexity, I'm considering writing a Python script to analyze glyph types in the font first, which will guide the C implementation. The end goal is a basic rasterizer using supersampling and flattened quadratic curves to render glyph outlines properly. Its a detailed process, but tackling it incrementally feels promising.

payload.arguments:
{"command":["bash","-lc","python3 - <<'PY'
import struct
from pathlib import Path
path = Path('SF-Pro.ttf')
if not path.exists():
    raise SystemExit('font not found')
data = path.read_bytes()

# helpers
ru16=lambda o: struct.unpack_from('>H',data,o)[0]
ru32=lambda o: struct.unpack_from('>I',data,o)[0]
ri16=lambda o: struct.unpack_from('>h',data,o)[0]

numTables=ru16(4)
tables={}
for i in range(numTables):
    off=12+i*16
    tag=data[off:off+4].decode('ascii')
    tables[tag]=(ru32(off+8),ru32(off+12))

head_off, head_len = tables['head']
unitsPerEm = ru16(head_off+18)
indexToLocFormat = ri16(head_off+50)
maxp_off,_=tables['maxp']
numGlyphs=ru16(maxp_off+4)
loca_off,_=tables['loca']
if indexToLocFormat==0:
    glyph_offsets=[ru16(loca_off+2*i)*2 for i in range(numGlyphs+1)]
else:
    glyph_offsets=[ru32(loca_off+4*i) for i in range(numGlyphs+1)]

glyf_off,_=tables['glyf']

# cmap parse format 4
cmap_off,_=tables['cmap']
numSubtables=ru16(cmap_off+2)
best=None
for i in range(numSubtables):
    off=cmap_off+4+i*8
    platform=ru16(off)
    encoding=ru16(off+2)
    sub_off=ru32(off+4)
    format=ru16(cmap_off+sub_off)
    if format==4 and platform in (0,3):
        best=cmap_off+sub_off
        break
if best is None:
    raise SystemExit('no cmap4')
segCount=ru16(best+6)//2
endCodes=[ru16(best+14+2*i) for i in range(segCount)]
startOffset=best+14+2*segCount+2
startCodes=[ru16(startOffset+2*i) for i in range(segCount)]
idDeltaOffset=startOffset+2*segCount
idDeltas=[ri16(idDeltaOffset+2*i) for i in range(segCount)]
idRangeOffsetOffset=idDeltaOffset+2*segCount
idRangeOffsets=[ru16(idRangeOffsetOffset+2*i) for i in range(segCount)]


def glyph_for(cp):
    for i,(start,end) in enumerate(zip(startCodes,endCodes)):
        if start<=cp<=end:
            ro=idRangeOffsets[i]
            if ro==0:
                return (cp + idDeltas[i]) & 0xFFFF
            idx=(ro//2 + (cp-start))
            loc=idRangeOffsetOffset+2*i+2*idx
            glyph=ru16(loc)
            if glyph==0:
                return 0
            return (glyph + idDeltas[i]) & 0xFFFF
    return 0

chars='ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789'
for ch in chars:
    g = glyph_for(ord(ch))
    off = glyph_offsets[g]
    off2 = glyph_offsets[g+1]
    if off==off2:
        contours=0
    else:
        contours=ri16(glyf_off+off)
    print(ch, g, contours)
PY"],"workdir":"/Users/alex/Documents/Projects/alix"}

payload.text:
**Designing TTF parsing and rendering plan**

I'm working through a detailed plan to parse TrueType font tables, handle glyph outlines, and flatten quadratic curves into line segments for rasterization, balancing correctness and complexity while considering future expandability for composite glyphs and efficient data structures.

**Detailing cmap4 and glyph metric parsing**

I'm working through the structure and parsing logic for the cmap format 4 character map, focusing on using raw table pointers to efficiently resolve glyph indices, and planning careful handling of font metric tables like `hmtx` to read advance widths and bearings on demand without unnecessary copies.

**Designing glyph rasterization and CLI argument support**

Im outlining how to convert glyph coordinates to pixel bitmaps with vertical flipping and bounding calculations, including custom float rounding and math helpers for a freestanding environment. I also plan a userland demo app that loads TTF fonts via CLI arguments, which means implementing argument passing through the kernel and shell commands to spawn processes with parameters.

summary.text:
**Designing TTF parsing and rendering plan**

I'm working through a detailed plan to parse TrueType font tables, handle glyph outlines, and flatten quadratic curves into line segments for rasterization, balancing correctness and complexity while considering future expandability for composite glyphs and efficient data structures.

**Detailing cmap4 and glyph metric parsing**

I'm working through the structure and parsing logic for the cmap format 4 character map, focusing on using raw table pointers to efficiently resolve glyph indices, and planning careful handling of font metric tables like `hmtx` to read advance widths and bearings on demand without unnecessary copies.

**Designing glyph rasterization and CLI argument support**

Im outlining how to convert glyph coordinates to pixel bitmaps with vertical flipping and bounding calculations, including custom float rounding and math helpers for a freestanding environment. I also plan a userland demo app that loads TTF fonts via CLI arguments, which means implementing argument passing through the kernel and shell commands to spawn processes with parameters.

payload.text:
**Designing process argument handling and stack setup**

I'm planning a simple whitespace tokenizer for command arguments in `runelf` to pass them as `argv` to the user ELF process, updating process creation to store and package these arguments on the user stack properly. I'll extend process structs and setup functions to manage `argc`, `argv` copies, and ensure correct stack alignment and register initialization for process startup. This includes implementing cloning, packing, and freeing of argument storage, updating thread bootstrap structure, and modifying system calls to support argument passing. I'll keep parsing minimalno quote handlingto keep it straightforward for now. I'll also prepare positioning for a new user app (`ttf_demo`) that accepts command line arguments.

payload.text:
**Designing TTF file reading and rendering**

I'm planning to read the entire TTF file dynamically since no file size info is available, using `open` and iterative `read` with `realloc`. Then I'll load the font with the TTF library and render glyphs `A-Z0-9` in a grid using ATK userland libs, probably creating an `atk_image` widget with an RGB565 composite image of glyph bitmaps converted from grayscale. I need to verify the `atk_image` API to confirm image loading steps.

payload.text:
**Designing TTF demo app and library integration**

I'm laying out a detailed plan to build a TTF font demo app: creating an RGB565 image atlas of glyphs with precise baseline alignment, adding window UI elements to show font info, and tightly integrating a new TTF library into the kernel and user space. Im carefully defining data structures, metrics calculations, rendering steps, glyph layout, and build system updates to ensure smooth loading, rendering, and display of font glyphs with all necessary resource management and tolerance for errors. This is a big but exciting feature to show off true type font rendering in the environment!

payload.text:
**Designing TTF library internals**

Im mapping out the TTF librarys internal structures and loading process, focusing on a clean API with opaque font structs, careful table parsing, and glyph lookup logic. There is a lot going on, especially around format 4 cmap parsing, glyph data extraction, and scaling  all aiming for robust TrueType font rendering!

**Implementing outline edge buffering and rasterization**

Im outlining how to convert glyph contours into edge lists with proper handling of on-curve/off-curve points and implied midpoints, then rasterize by supersampling using a winding-number test. This involves carefully building expanded point arrays, emitting line and quadratic segments, computing bounding boxes, and producing antialiased bitmaps. Its a detailed but manageable plan to draw glyph shapes accurately!

**Designing helper functions and header interface**

Im focused on creating robust helper functions for edge list management, quadratic flattening, contour emission, and memory safety, along with handling glyph metrics and rasterization. Im also planning a clean public header file to expose core font loading, metrics retrieval, glyph lookup, rendering, and bitmap management functions to any user of the library. This careful groundwork should make the TTF library both safe and easy to integrate!

This involves carefully building expanded point arrays, emitting line and quadratic segments, computing bounding boxes, and producing antialiased bitmaps. Its a detailed but manageable plan to draw glyph shapes accurately!

This careful groundwork should make the TTF library both safe and easy to integrate!

Im weighing whether to rewrite the TTF library to use fixed-point math or adjust compiler flags to allow x87 floating-point (avoiding SSE) under `-mgeneral-regs-only`. Adding `-mfpmath=387 -mno-sse` to the Makefiles `CFLAGS` might let floats compile without SSE, which could be a simpler fix than a full rewrite to integer arithmetic.

payload.text:
**Replacing float-returning helpers with macros**

Im planning to remove all static float helper functions like ttf_absf and replace them with GCC-specific inline macros using statement expressions to avoid any functions returning float, which causes compiler errors without SSE. This approach keeps float operations inline and should satisfy compiler constraints while preserving functionality.

payload.text:
**Planning integer-based TTF rewrite**

I'm working through a detailed plan to reimplement `src/kernel/ttf.c` using integer math and fixed-point arithmetic. I'll rebuild table parsing, glyph decoding, outline processing, and rasterization with fixed-point macros and 64-bit scaling to maintain precision, carefully designing each step to replace the prior float-based approach. This involves recreating all key components from scratch with integer types and fixed-point helpers, ensuring accuracy while managing complexity in scaling, rounding, and edge calculations.

payload.text:
**Summarizing TTF demo and CLI enhancements**

I've gathered key details for the final summary, including the new TTF library and user demo app, expanded argument support in user programs, build updates, usage instructions, and testing results. I'll organize everything with file references and line numbers, note limitations like missing composite glyph support, and include clear next-step suggestions for running and integrating the demo.

payload.message:
**TTF Library & Demo**
- Implemented a full fixed-point TrueType rasterizer that parses `head/maxp/cmap/loca/hmtx`, converts outlines to 26.6 fixed-point geometry, flattens quadratic curves, and rasterizes via 22 supersampling to grayscale bitmaps with metrics (`src/kernel/ttf.c:1-362` & `src/kernel/ttf.c:600-842`). New public API exposes opaque font handles plus bitmap/metric structs (`include/ttf.h:6-49`). (Note: composite glyphs still fall back to `.notdef` for now.)
- Added a user-space ATK demo that loads a TTF file, renders glyphs AZ/09 using the new library, builds an RGB565 atlas with simple alpha blending, and shows it in a themed window with full event handling (`user/ttf_demo.c:66-442`).

**User Arg Plumbing**
- Extended process structures and bootstrap flow to clone argv arrays, pack them on the user stack, and seed RDI/RSI before iret, enabling true command-line arguments for userland (`src/kernel/process.c:160-858`). Updated `_start` to forward argc/argv to `main` (`user/crt0.c:1-9`).
- Exposed argv-aware process creation APIs (`include/process.h:112-120`) and taught `cmd_runelf` to tokenize command strings, forward argv to processes, and clean up allocations (`src/sbin/cmd_runelf.c:7-134`). The helper commands that spawn user programs now call the new signature (`src/sbin/cmd_useratk.c:25-39`, `src/sbin/cmd_userdemo2.c:18-36`).

**Build & Tooling**
- Ensured both kernel and user builds compile `ttf.c`, enabled soft-float-friendly flags (`-mfpmath=387 -mno-sse`), and introduced the `ttf_demo` ELF/bin targets so the binary lands in `build/bin/ttf_demo` (`Makefile:19-127`).
- `ttf_demo` can be launched inside the OS shell via `runelf /bin/ttf_demo /build/SF-Pro.ttf 96`, thanks to the new argument pipeline.

**Testing & Usage**
- Ran `make` to build the kernel, loader, and all user binaries (verified `ttf_demo` links against ATK and the TTF library). Didnt boot QEMU here.
- Usage: copy a `.ttf` into the data image, boot the OS, run `runelf /bin/ttf_demo /path/to/font.ttf 72` to see the glyph atlas. `runelf` now accepts additional args for any user program.

**Next steps**
1. Boot the OS, run `runelf /bin/ttf_demo ` with fonts of interest, and watch for composite/extended glyph behavior.
2. Consider wiring `ttf_font_render_glyph_bitmap` into ATK text widgets so the rest of the UI can switch from bitmap fonts to scalable type.

**TTF Library & Demo**
- Implemented a full fixed-point TrueType rasterizer that parses `head/maxp/cmap/loca/hmtx`, converts outlines to 26.6 fixed-point geometry, flattens quadratic curves, and rasterizes via 22 supersampling to grayscale bitmaps with metrics (`src/kernel/ttf.c:1-362` & `src/kernel/ttf.c:600-842`). New public API exposes opaque font handles plus bitmap/metric structs (`include/ttf.h:6-49`). (Note: composite glyphs still fall back to `.notdef` for now.)
- Added a user-space ATK demo that loads a TTF file, renders glyphs AZ/09 using the new library, builds an RGB565 atlas with simple alpha blending, and shows it in a themed window with full event handling (`user/ttf_demo.c:66-442`).

**User Arg Plumbing**
- Extended process structures and bootstrap flow to clone argv arrays, pack them on the user stack, and seed RDI/RSI before iret, enabling true command-line arguments for userland (`src/kernel/process.c:160-858`). Updated `_start` to forward argc/argv to `main` (`user/crt0.c:1-9`).
- Exposed argv-aware process creation APIs (`include/process.h:112-120`) and taught `cmd_runelf` to tokenize command strings, forward argv to processes, and clean up allocations (`src/sbin/cmd_runelf.c:7-134`). The helper commands that spawn user programs now call the new signature (`src/sbin/cmd_useratk.c:25-39`, `src/sbin/cmd_userdemo2.c:18-36`).

**Build & Tooling**
- Ensured both kernel and user builds compile `ttf.c`, enabled soft-float-friendly flags (`-mfpmath=387 -mno-sse`), and introduced the `ttf_demo` ELF/bin targets so the binary lands in `build/bin/ttf_demo` (`Makefile:19-127`).
- `ttf_demo` can be launched inside the OS shell via `runelf /bin/ttf_demo /build/SF-Pro.ttf 96`, thanks to the new argument pipeline.

**Testing & Usage**
- Ran `make` to build the kernel, loader, and all user binaries (verified `ttf_demo` links against ATK and the TTF library). Didnt boot QEMU here.
- Usage: copy a `.ttf` into the data image, boot the OS, run `runelf /bin/ttf_demo /path/to/font.ttf 72` to see the glyph atlas. `runelf` now accepts additional args for any user program.

**Next steps**
1. Boot the OS, run `runelf /bin/ttf_demo ` with fonts of interest, and watch for composite/extended glyph behavior.
2. Consider wiring `ttf_font_render_glyph_bitmap` into ATK text widgets so the rest of the UI can switch from bitmap fonts to scalable type.

**Analyzing cause of general protection fault**

I'm tracing the general protection fault triggered during process_jump_to_user; it seems linked to invalid stack or segment values, possibly due to a non-canonical or unmapped user stack pointer being pushed onto the kernel stack. Im exploring the code paths that set or clear the user stack pointer, suspecting type or assignment issues where a host pointer might be erroneously used instead of a user pointer. This involves checking how user_initial_stack and user_stack_top are assigned and whether zeroing or clearing logic could cause invalid stack pointers leading to the fault.

payload.text:
**Proposing register-safe assembly rewrite**

Im working out a plan to fix the inline assembly by moving each value into a dedicated register (like RAX) immediately before pushing it. This avoids the compiler reusing registers for different operands and ensures the correct values go onto the stack before the `iretq`. I'll revise `process_jump_to_user` to do these explicit moves for all pushed values so the #GP fault due to incorrect stack frame can be fixed reliably.

payload.text:
**Summarizing fix and next steps**

I'll explain the root cause was inline assembly register reuse causing wrong pushes leading to a general protection fault, and the fix was loading each value into rax before pushing to ensure correctness. I'll mention that user_demo should boot now, note we built the kernel but didn't run the OS yet, and suggest verifying by re-running the OS. I'll highlight the fix locations with file paths and line numbers, provide instructions to run tests via make, and recommend booting next to confirm everything works.

payload.message:
- `process_jump_to_user` was still using the inline `push %[ss]/[cs]/` sequence from before we added argc/argv, but the new operands let the compiler reuse registers for multiple inputs. In practice the `[ss]`, `[cs]`, etc. operands ended up sharing registers with `[argc]`/`[argv]`, so by the time the `push` instructions ran we were no longer pushing the segment selectors and RIP we thoughtwe were pushing the argument values. When `iretq` tried to return to user mode with garbage CS/SS and stack pointers, the CPU raised the #GP you saw (RIP 0x106c4b).  
- Fixed by explicitly staging each selector/value into `%rax` immediately before the corresponding `push`, so the assembler can no longer substitute the same register for multiple operands (`src/kernel/process.c:1379-1418`). The rest of the iret frame now matches the intended SS/RSP/RFLAGS/CS/RIP ordering regardless of how the compiler assigns registers.
- Rebuilt everything with `make` to ensure the kernel and user binaries incorporate the fix.

Please rebuild/boot the OS (e.g. `make run-hdd`) to confirm `user_demo` starts cleanly again.

- `process_jump_to_user` was still using the inline `push %[ss]/[cs]/` sequence from before we added argc/argv, but the new operands let the compiler reuse registers for multiple inputs. In practice the `[ss]`, `[cs]`, etc. operands ended up sharing registers with `[argc]`/`[argv]`, so by the time the `push` instructions ran we were no longer pushing the segment selectors and RIP we thoughtwe were pushing the argument values. When `iretq` tried to return to user mode with garbage CS/SS and stack pointers, the CPU raised the #GP you saw (RIP 0x106c4b).  
- Fixed by explicitly staging each selector/value into `%rax` immediately before the corresponding `push`, so the assembler can no longer substitute the same register for multiple operands (`src/kernel/process.c:1379-1418`). The rest of the iret frame now matches the intended SS/RSP/RFLAGS/CS/RIP ordering regardless of how the compiler assigns registers.
- Rebuilt everything with `make` to ensure the kernel and user binaries incorporate the fix.

Please rebuild/boot the OS (e.g. `make run-hdd`) to confirm `user_demo` starts cleanly again.

**Investigating stack alignment and pointer issues causing faults**

There's a lot going on here, but Im focusing on how stack alignment, pointer values, and memory copying might cause general protection faults. Im checking whether kernel vs user pointers are mixed up, if stack alignment is off causing overwritten data, or if memory operations like memcpy touch invalid or freed pointers. The canonical address checks and size calculations look okay, but subtle pointer or alignment mishandling might explain repeated faults before switching to user code. Ill keep exploring register values and memory mappings to narrow down this tricky issue.

payload.message:
That #GP still happened because the compiler kept reusing `rdi/rsi` for the selector values we push onto the IRET frame. Even though we moved the selectors into `%rax` first, GCC observed that `rdi` wasnt needed later (since we hadnt yet reloaded argc/argv) and happily reassigned it to hold `ss`, so the first `push` wrote the processs argc instead of the user SS value. Then `ss=argc` caused the `iretq` to fault.

The fix was to move the `mov %[argc], %%rdi` / `mov %[argv], %%rsi` instructions to the *end* of the inline asm, after we have finished pushing the frame. That lets the compiler use whatever registers it wants for `ss/cs/rflags/entry` without clobbering the values we eventually load into `%rdi/%rsi`, and ensures the pushes now truly use the selector constants.

File touched:
- `src/kernel/process.c`: inline asm in `process_jump_to_user` now loads `rdi/rsi` only right before `iretq`.

Rebuilt with `make` (kernel + EFI) to capture the change.

Please re-run the OS; `user_demo` should now transition cleanly (and user processes will still receive argc/argv correctly).

Then `ss=argc` caused the `iretq` to fault.

The fix was to move the `mov %[argc], %%rdi` / `mov %[argv], %%rsi` instructions to the *end* of the inline asm, after we have finished pushing the frame. That lets the compiler use whatever registers it wants for `ss/cs/rflags/entry` without clobbering the values we eventually load into `%rdi/%rsi`, and ensures the pushes now truly use the selector constants.

summary.text:
**Addressing zombie processes cleanup**

Im planning to fix zombie user processes left by shell commands by ensuring `process_destroy` is called right after `process_join` in key command files like `cmd_userdemo2.c`, `cmd_useratk.c`, and `cmd_runelf.c`. I want to add a helper call to clean up processes after theyve joined, avoiding any double-free issues and making sure zombies dont accumulate. Ill search for all relevant process creation sites to confirm where cleanup is needed and update accordingly.

payload.text:
**Summarizing process cleanup fix**

I'll explain that all user process-spawning commands now properly destroy processes after joining, preventing zombie processes. I'll also suggest running tests by building the project to observe the fix in action.

payload.message:
Processes were sticking around because the shell utilities that spawn user tasks (runelf/userdemo2/useratk) were only `process_join`ing them. Join waits for the thread to enter `PROCESS_STATE_ZOMBIE`, but it never frees the PCB; without a follow-up `process_destroy` those entries linger forever.

What changed:
- `cmd_runelf.c`, `cmd_useratk.c`, and `cmd_userdemo2.c` now call `process_destroy(proc)` immediately after `process_join(...)` completes, ensuring every ELF process they launch is reaped once it exits (`src/sbin/cmd_runelf.c`, `src/sbin/cmd_useratk.c`, `src/sbin/cmd_userdemo2.c`).
- Rebuilt via `make` so the shell picks up the fix.

Now when you run `runelf`, `useratk`, or `userdemo2`, the spawned user process is properly destroyed after it finishes, so the process list no longer accumulates zombies.
